portfolio-sidebar.question: Why I design technology, you ask...
portfolio-sidebar.answer: started with a desire to explore science and technology, I begin to dive into making it. Soon after, I realize before making technology I have to learn designing technology considering people who will be using it. It changed my perspective about how I used to design atechnology driven experience, from a technology centric design to human centric design. Now it's a passion!

about.intro:
You may have heard of computer scientist, programmer, visual designer, experience designer, research designer, interface designer and many other designers, but what the heck is wildcard design technologist?

It's someone, none of the above, Or, all of the above! Someone who does curiosity driven exploration with an agile mind in design and technology, who is not afraid of the unexpected but embraces it and thrive on it. Someone who knows their stuff inside and out, but still keep an open mind and always keen to learn. Someone who is facinated by different perspectives. Someone who is creative and have passion, who posses a big bag of tricks in variety of areas realted to design and technology.

So, yes I am a Wildcard design technologist. I design technology and then try to build it. Sometime I succeed, sometimes I face failure. But what doesn't kill you makes you stronger. Everytime I fail, I learn more than when I succeed.

publications.title: SynKu: Exploring the Production of Sensory Objects
publications.citation: Ankur Agrawal, Wenvi Hidayat, Aravind Ravi, Mark Stamnes, Meishen Yin, and Daniela Rosner. 2015. SynKu: Exploring the Production of Sensory Objects. In Proceedings of the 33rd Annual ACM Conference Extended Abstracts on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI EA '15). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 2121-2126. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/2702613.2732813

publications.title: Designing for Movement in Public Life with Itinerant Probes
publications.citation: Daniela K. Rosner, Margaret E. Morris, Ariel Duncan, Sarah E. Fox, Kathi R. Kitner, Ankur Agrawal, and Mei J. Chen. 2016. Designing for Movement in Public Life with Itinerant Probes. In Proceedings of the 2016 ACM Conference on Designing Interactive Systems (DIS '16). ACM, New York, NY, USA, 1072-1082. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1145/2901790.2901913
